# On-demand API examples
Used to fetch articles in their latest revision/version from all supported projects and languages. 
Allows filtering and field selection. Allows to limit articles when doing cross-project, cross-language lookup.
Refer to the documentation [here](https://enterprise.wikimedia.com/docs/on-demand/#article-lookup).
The articles are based on [this](https://gitlab.wikimedia.org/repos/wme/wikimedia-enterprise/-/blob/main/general/schema/article.go) schema.



i) Get articles with name `Montreal` from all projects in all languages. 

```bash
POST https://api.enterprise.wikimedia.com/v2/articles/Montreal
```

with request parameter:
```json
{
  "limit": 10
}
```
Note: Max allowed limit is 10. Default limit is 3.

        "abstract": "Montreal is the second most populous city in Canada, the tenth most populous city in North America, and the most populous city in the province of Quebec. Founded in 1642 as Ville-Marie, or \"City of Mary\", it is named after Mount Royal, the triple-peaked hill around which the early city of Ville-Marie was built. The city is centred on the Island of Montreal, which obtained its name from the same origin as the city, and a few much smaller peripheral islands, the largest of which is Île Bizard. The city is 196 km (122 mi) east of the national capital, Ottawa, and 258 km (160 mi) southwest of the provincial capital, Quebec City. As of 2021, the city has a population of 1,762,949, and a metropolitan population of 4,291,732, making it the second-largest city, and second-largest metropolitan area in Canada. French is the city's official language. In 2021, 85.7% of the population of the city of Montreal considered themselves fluent in French while 90.2% could speak it in the metropolitan area. Montreal is one of the most bilingual cities in Quebec and Canada, with 58.5% of the population able to speak both English and French. Historically the commercial capital of Canada, Montreal was surpassed in population and economic strength by Toronto in the 1970s. Montreal remains an important centre of art, culture, literature, film and television, music, commerce, aerospace, transport, finance, pharmaceuticals, technology, design, education, tourism, food, fashion, video game development, and world affairs. Montreal is the location of the headquarters of the International Civil Aviation Organization, and was named a UNESCO City of Design in 2006. In 2017, Montreal was ranked the 12th-most liveable city in the world by the Economist Intelligence Unit in its annual Global Liveability Ranking, although it slipped to rank 40 in the 2021 index, primarily due to stress on the healthcare system from the COVID-19 pandemic. It is regularly ranked as a top ten city in the world to be a university student in the QS World University Rankings. Montreal has hosted multiple international conferences and events, including the 1967 International and Universal Exposition and the 1976 Summer Olympics. It is the only Canadian city to have held the Summer Olympics. In 2018, Montreal was ranked as a global city. The city hosts the Canadian Grand Prix of Formula One; the Montreal International Jazz Festival, the largest jazz festival in the world; the Just for Laughs festival, the largest comedy festival in the world; and Les Francos de Montréal, the largest French-language music festival in the world. In sports, it is home to the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League, who have won the Stanley Cup more times than any other team.",

Arriving in 1535, Cartier was the first European to visit the area.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mw-w\"><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Archaeological\" title=\"Archaeological\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mw_A\">Archaeological</a> evidence in the region indicate that <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./First_Nations_in_Canada\" title=\"First Nations in Canada\" id=\"mw_Q\">First Nations</a> native people occupied the island of Montreal as early as 4,000 years ago.<sup about=\"#mwt347\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-53\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-53\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-53\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 53;\" id=\"mw_g\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mw_w\">[53]</span></a></sup> By the year AD 1000, they had started to cultivate <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Maize\" title=\"Maize\" id=\"mwAQA\">maize</a>. Within a few hundred years, they had built <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Fortified\" title=\"Fortified\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAQE\">fortified</a> villages.<sup about=\"#mwt351\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-54\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-54\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-54\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 54;\" id=\"mwAQI\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAQM\">[54]</span></a></sup> The <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Saint_Lawrence_Iroquoians\" title=\"Saint Lawrence Iroquoians\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAQQ\">Saint Lawrence Iroquoians</a>, an ethnically and culturally distinct group from the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Iroquois\" title=\"Iroquois\" id=\"mwAQU\">Iroquois</a> nations of the <i id=\"mwAQY\"><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Haudenosaunee\" title=\"Haudenosaunee\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAQc\">Haudenosaunee</a></i> (then based in present-day New York), established the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Hochelaga_(village)\" title=\"Hochelaga (village)\" id=\"mwAQg\">village of Hochelaga</a> at the foot of Mount Royal two centuries before the French arrived. Archeologists have found evidence of their habitation there and at other locations in the valley since at least the 14th<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwAQk\"> </span>century.<sup about=\"#mwt355\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Tremblay_55-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Tremblay\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Tremblay-55\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Tremblay-55\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 55;\" id=\"mwAQo\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAQs\">[55]</span></a></sup>\nThe French explorer Jacques Cartier visited <i id=\"mwAQw\">Hochelaga</i> on October 2, 1535, and estimated the population of the native people at Hochelaga to be \"over a thousand people\".<sup about=\"#mwt357\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Tremblay_55-1\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Tremblay\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Tremblay-55\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 55;\" id=\"mwAQ0\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAQ4\">[55]</span></a></sup> Evidence of earlier occupation of the island, such as those uncovered in 1642 during the construction of Fort Ville-Marie, have effectively been removed.</p>\n\n</section><section data-mw-section-id=\"4\" id=\"mwAQ8\"><h3 id=\"Early_European_settlement_(1600–1760)\"><span id=\"Early_European_settlement_.281600.E2.80.931760.29\" typeof=\"mw:FallbackId\"></span>Early European settlement (1600–1760)</h3>\n<p id=\"mwARA\">In 1603, French explorer <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Samuel_de_Champlain\" title=\"Samuel de Champlain\" id=\"mwARE\">Samuel de Champlain</a> reported that the St<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwARI\"> </span>Lawrence Iroquoians and their settlements had disappeared altogether from the St<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwARM\"> </span>Lawrence valley. This is believed to be due to outmigration, epidemics of European diseases, or intertribal wars.<sup about=\"#mwt362\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Tremblay_55-2\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Tremblay\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Tremblay-55\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 55;\" id=\"mwARQ\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwARU\">[55]</span></a></sup><sup about=\"#mwt364\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-56\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-56\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-56\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 56;\" id=\"mwARY\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwARc\">[56]</span></a></sup> In 1611, Champlain established a <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Fur\" title=\"Fur\" id=\"mwARg\">fur</a> <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Trading_post\" title=\"Trading post\" id=\"mwARk\">trading post</a> on the Island of Montreal on a site initially named <i id=\"mwARo\">La Place Royale</i>. At the confluence of <i id=\"mwARs\">Petite Riviere</i> and St. Lawrence River, it is where present-day <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Pointe-à-Callière\" title=\"Pointe-à-Callière\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwARw\">Pointe-à-Callière</a> stands.<sup about=\"#mwt368\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Marsan_57-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Marsan\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Marsan-57\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Marsan-57\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 57;\" id=\"mwAR0\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAR4\">[57]</span></a></sup> On his 1616 map, Champlain named the island Lille de Villemenon in honour of the sieur de Villemenon, a French dignitary who was seeking the viceroyship of New France.<sup about=\"#mwt372\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-58\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-58\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-58\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 58;\" id=\"mwAR8\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwASA\">[58]</span></a></sup> In 1639, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Jérôme_Le_Royer_de_La_Dauversière\" title=\"Jérôme Le Royer de La Dauversière\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwASE\">Jérôme Le Royer de La Dauversière</a> obtained the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Seigneurial_system_of_New_France\" title=\"Seigneurial system of New France\" id=\"mwASI\">Seigneurial title</a> to the Island of Montreal in the name of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Société_de_Notre-Dame_de_Montréal\" title=\"Société de Notre-Dame de Montréal\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwASM\">Notre Dame Society of Montreal</a> to establish a Roman Catholic <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Mission_(Christian)\" title=\"Mission (Christian)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwASQ\">mission</a> to <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Evangelize\" title=\"Evangelize\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwASU\">evangelize</a> natives.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwASY\"><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Jérome_le_Royer_de_la_Dauversiere\" title=\"Jérome le Royer de la Dauversiere\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwASc\">Dauversiere</a> hired <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Paul_Chomedey_de_Maisonneuve\" title=\"Paul Chomedey de Maisonneuve\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwASg\">Paul Chomedey de Maisonneuve</a>, then age 30, to lead a group of colonists to build a mission on his new seigneury. The colonists left France in 1641 for Quebec and arrived on the island the following year. On May 17, 1642, Ville-Marie was founded on the southern shore of Montreal island, with Maisonneuve as its first governor. The settlement included a chapel and a hospital, under the command of <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Jeanne_Mance\" title=\"Jeanne Mance\" id=\"mwASk\">Jeanne Mance</a>.<sup about=\"#mwt377\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Miquelon_59-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Miquelon\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Miquelon-59\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Miquelon-59\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 59;\" id=\"mwASo\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwASs\">[59]</span></a></sup> By 1643, Ville-Marie had come under Iroquois raids. In 1652, Maisonneuve returned to France to raise 100 volunteers to bolster the colonial population. If the effort had failed, Montreal was to be abandoned and the survivors re-located downriver to <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_City\" title=\"Quebec City\" id=\"mwASw\">Quebec City</a>. Before these 100 arrived in the fall of 1653, the population of Montreal was barely 50 people.</p>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size mw-halign-left\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\" id=\"mwAS0\"><a href=\"./File:Capitulation_Montreal.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\" id=\"mwAS4\"><img resource=\"./File:Capitulation_Montreal.jpg\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Capitulation_Montreal.jpg/220px-Capitulation_Montreal.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" data-file-width=\"1656\" data-file-height=\"1060\" data-file-type=\"bitmap\" height=\"141\" width=\"220\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Capitulation_Montreal.jpg/330px-Capitulation_Montreal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Capitulation_Montreal.jpg/440px-Capitulation_Montreal.jpg 2x\" class=\"mw-file-element\" id=\"mwAS8\"/></a><figcaption id=\"mwATA\">French authorities surrender the city of Montreal to the British after the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Articles_of_Capitulation_of_Montreal\" title=\"Articles of Capitulation of Montreal\" id=\"mwATE\">Articles of Capitulation</a> was signed in 1760.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mwATI\">By 1685, Ville-Marie was home to some 600 colonists, most of them living in modest wooden houses. Ville-Marie became a centre for the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Fur_trade\" title=\"Fur trade\" id=\"mwATM\">fur trade</a> and a base for further <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./French_colonization_of_the_Americas\" title=\"French colonization of the Americas\" id=\"mwATQ\">exploration</a>.<sup about=\"#mwt382\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Miquelon_59-1\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Miquelon\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Miquelon-59\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 59;\" id=\"mwATU\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwATY\">[59]</span></a></sup> In 1689, the English-allied Iroquois attacked <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Lachine_massacre\" title=\"Lachine massacre\" id=\"mwATc\">Lachine</a> on the Island of Montreal, committing the worst massacre in the history of New France.<sup about=\"#mwt386\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-60\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-60\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-60\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 60;\" id=\"mwATg\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwATk\">[60]</span></a></sup> By the early 18th<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwATo\"> </span>century, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Sulpician_Order\" title=\"Sulpician Order\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwATs\">Sulpician Order</a> was established there. To encourage French settlement, it wanted the Mohawk to move away from the fur trading post at Ville-Marie. It had a mission village, known as <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Kahnewake\" title=\"Kahnewake\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwATw\">Kahnewake</a>, south of the St Lawrence River. The fathers persuaded some Mohawk to make a new settlement at their former hunting grounds north of the Ottawa River. This became <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Kanesatake\" title=\"Kanesatake\" id=\"mwAT0\">Kanesatake</a>.<sup about=\"#mwt390\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-61\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-61\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-61\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 61;\" id=\"mwAT4\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAT8\">[61]</span></a></sup> In 1745, several Mohawk families moved upriver to create another settlement, known as <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Akwesasne\" title=\"Akwesasne\" id=\"mwAUA\">Akwesasne</a>. All three are now Mohawk reserves in Canada. The Canadian territory was ruled as a French colony until 1760, when <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montreal_Campaign\" title=\"Montreal Campaign\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAUE\">Montreal fell to a British offensive</a> during the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Seven_Years'_War\" title=\"Seven Years' War\" id=\"mwAUI\">Seven Years' War</a>. The colony then surrendered to Great Britain.<sup about=\"#mwt394\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Encarta_62-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Encarta\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Encarta-62\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Encarta-62\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 62;\" id=\"mwAUM\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAUQ\">[62]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAUU\">Ville-Marie was the name for the settlement that appeared in all official documents until 1705, when Montreal appeared for the first time, although people referred to the \"Island of Montreal\" long before then.<sup about=\"#mwt399\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-63\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-63\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-63\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 63;\" id=\"mwAUY\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAUc\">[63]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div style=\"clear:both;\" class=\"\" about=\"#mwt400\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"clear\",\"href\":\"./Template:Clear\"},\"params\":{},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAUg\"></div>\n\n</section><section data-mw-section-id=\"5\" id=\"mwAUk\"><h3 id=\"American_occupation_(1775–1776)\"><span id=\"American_occupation_.281775.E2.80.931776.29\" typeof=\"mw:FallbackId\"></span>American occupation (1775–1776)</h3>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate=\"TemplateStyles:r1097763485\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion\" about=\"#mwt401\" Unsourced material may be challenged and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence\" title=\"Wikipedia:Verifiability\">removed</a>.</span>  <span class=\"date-container\"><i>(<span class=\"date\">May 2022</span>)</i></span><span class=\"hide-when-compact\"><i> (<small><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Help:Maintenance_template_removal\" title=\"Help:Maintenance template removal\">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a></small>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table><link rel=\"mw:PageProp/Category\" href=\"./Category:Articles_needing_additional_references_from_May_2022\" about=\"#mwt401\"/><link rel=\"mw:PageProp/Category\" href=\"./Category:All_articles_needing_additional_references\" about=\"#mwt401\" id=\"mwAUs\"/>\n<p id=\"mwAUw\">As part of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./American_Revolution\" title=\"American Revolution\" id=\"mwAU0\">American Revolution</a>, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Invasion_of_Quebec_(1775)\" title=\"Invasion of Quebec (1775)\" id=\"mwAU4\">invasion of Quebec</a> resulted after <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Benedict_Arnold\" title=\"Benedict Arnold\" id=\"mwAU8\">Benedict Arnold</a> captured <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Fort_Ticonderoga\" title=\"Fort Ticonderoga\" id=\"mwAVA\">Fort Ticonderoga</a> in present-day upstate New York in May 1775 as a launching point to <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Benedict_Arnold's_expedition_to_Quebec\" title=\"Benedict Arnold's expedition to Quebec\" id=\"mwAVE\">Arnold's invasion of Quebec in September</a>. While Arnold approached the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Plains_of_Abraham\" title=\"Plains of Abraham\" id=\"mwAVI\">Plains of Abraham</a>, Montreal fell to American forces led by <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Richard_Montgomery\" title=\"Richard Montgomery\" id=\"mwAVM\">Richard Montgomery</a> on November 13, 1775, after it was abandoned by <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Guy_Carleton,_1st_Baron_Dorchester\" title=\"Guy Carleton, 1st Baron Dorchester\" id=\"mwAVQ\">Guy Carleton</a>. After Arnold withdrew from Quebec City to <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Pointe-aux-Trembles\" title=\"Pointe-aux-Trembles\" id=\"mwAVU\">Pointe-aux-Trembles</a> on November 19, Montgomery's forces left Montreal on December 1 and arrived there on December 3 to plot to <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Battle_of_Quebec_(1775)\" title=\"Battle of Quebec (1775)\" id=\"mwAVY\">attack Quebec City</a>, with Montgomery leaving <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./David_Wooster\" title=\"David Wooster\" id=\"mwAVc\">David Wooster</a> in charge of the city. Montgomery was killed in the failed attack and Arnold, who had taken command, sent Brigadier General <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Moses_Hazen\" title=\"Moses Hazen\" id=\"mwAVg\">Moses Hazen</a> to inform Wooster of the defeat.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAVk\">Wooster left Hazen in command on March 20, 1776, as he left to replace Arnold in leading further attacks on Quebec City. On April 19, Arnold arrived in Montreal to take over command from Hazen, who remained as his second-in-command. Hazen sent Colonel <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Timothy_Bedel\" title=\"Timothy Bedel\" id=\"mwAVo\">Timothy Bedel</a> to form a garrison of 390 men 40 miles upriver in a garrison at <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Les_Cèdres,_Quebec\" title=\"Les Cèdres, Quebec\" id=\"mwAVs\">Les Cèdres, Quebec</a>, to defend Montreal against the British army. In the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Battle_of_the_Cedars\" title=\"Battle of the Cedars\" id=\"mwAVw\">Battle of the Cedars</a>, Bedel's lieutenant <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Isaac_Butterfield\" title=\"Isaac Butterfield\" id=\"mwAV0\">Isaac Butterfield</a> surrendered to George Forster.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAV4\">Forster advanced to <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Fort_Senneville\" title=\"Fort Senneville\" id=\"mwAV8\">Fort Senneville</a> on May 23. By May 24, Arnold was entrenched in <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Lachine,_Quebec\" title=\"Lachine, Quebec\" id=\"mwAWA\">Montreal's borough of Lachine</a>. Forster initially approached Lachine, then withdrew to <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quinze-Chênes?action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" title=\"Quinze-Chênes\" class=\"new\" typeof=\"mw:LocalizedAttrs\" data-mw-i18n='{\"title\":{\"lang\":\"x-page\",\"key\":\"red-link-title\",\"params\":[\"Quinze-Chênes\"]}}' id=\"mwAWE\">Quinze-Chênes</a>. Arnold's forces then abandoned Lachine to chase Forster. The Americans burned Senneville on May 26. After Arnold crossed the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Ottawa_River\" title=\"Ottawa River\" id=\"mwAWI\">Ottawa River</a> in pursuit of Forster, Forster's cannons repelled Arnold's forces. Forster negotiated a prisoner exchange with <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Henry_Sherburne\" title=\"Henry Sherburne\" id=\"mwAWM\">Henry Sherburne</a> and Isaac Butterfield, resulting in a May 27 boating of their deputy Lieutenant Park being returned to the Americans. Arnold and Forster negotiated further and more American prisoners were returned to Arnold at <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Sainte-Anne-de-Bellevue,_Quebec\" title=\"Sainte-Anne-de-Bellevue, Quebec\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAWQ\">Sainte-Anne-de-Bellevue, Quebec</a>, (\"Fort Anne\") on May 30 (delayed two days by wind).</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAWU\">Arnold eventually withdrew his forces back to the New York fort of Ticonderoga by the summer. On June 15, Arnold's messenger approaching <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Sorel-Tracy\" title=\"Sorel-Tracy\" id=\"mwAWY\">Sorel</a> spotted Carleton returning with a fleet of ships and notified him. Arnold's forces abandoned Montreal (attempting to burn it down in the process) prior to the June 17 arrival of Carleton's fleet.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAWc\">The Americans did not return British prisoners in exchange, as previously agreed, due to accusations of abuse, with Congress repudiating the agreement at the protest of George Washington. Arnold blamed Colonel Timothy Bedel for the defeat, removing him and Lieutenant Butterfield from command and sending them to Sorel for court-martial. The retreat of the American army delayed their court martial until August 1, 1776, when they were convicted and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Cashiered\" title=\"Cashiered\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAWg\">cashiered</a> at Ticonderoga. Bedel was given a new commission by Congress in October 1777 after Arnold was assigned to defend Rhode Island in <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Military_career_of_Benedict_Arnold,_1777–1779\" title=\"Military career of Benedict Arnold, 1777–1779\" id=\"mwAWk\">July 1777</a>.</p>\n\n</section><section data-mw-section-id=\"6\" id=\"mwAWo\"><h3 id=\"Modern_history_as_city_(1832–present)\"><span id=\"Modern_history_as_city_.281832.E2.80.93present.29\" typeof=\"mw:FallbackId\"></span>Modern history as city (1832–present)</h3>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096\" about=\"#mwt404\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"See also\",\"href\":\"./Template:See_also\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"Municipal history of Quebec\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAWs\"/><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\" about=\"#mwt404\" id=\"mwAWw\">See also: <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Municipal_history_of_Quebec\" title=\"Municipal history of Quebec\">Municipal history of Quebec</a></div>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\" id=\"mwAW0\"><a href=\"./File:Lachine_Canal,_Montreal,_1826.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\" id=\"mwAW4\"><img resource=\"./File:Lachine_Canal,_Montreal,_1826.jpg\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Lachine_Canal%2C_Montreal%2C_1826.jpg/220px-Lachine_Canal%2C_Montreal%2C_1826.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" data-file-width=\"1129\" data-file-height=\"568\" data-file-type=\"bitmap\" height=\"111\" width=\"220\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Lachine_Canal%2C_Montreal%2C_1826.jpg/330px-Lachine_Canal%2C_Montreal%2C_1826.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Lachine_Canal%2C_Montreal%2C_1826.jpg/440px-Lachine_Canal%2C_Montreal%2C_1826.jpg 2x\" class=\"mw-file-element\" id=\"mwAW8\"/></a><figcaption id=\"mwAXA\">View of <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Lachine_Canal\" title=\"Lachine Canal\" id=\"mwAXE\">Lachine Canal</a> in 1826, a year after it opened. It bypassed the rapids west of the city, linking Montreal with other continental markets.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mwAXI\">Montreal was incorporated as a city in 1832.<sup about=\"#mwt414\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-64\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-64\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-64\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 64;\" id=\"mwAXM\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAXQ\">[64]</span></a></sup> The opening of the Lachine Canal permitted ships to bypass the unnavigable <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Lachine_Rapids\" title=\"Lachine Rapids\" id=\"mwAXU\">Lachine Rapids</a>,<sup about=\"#mwt418\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Parks_Canada_65-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Parks Canada\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Parks_Canada-65\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Parks_Canada-65\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 65;\" id=\"mwAXY\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAXc\">[65]</span></a></sup> while the construction of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Victoria_Bridge_(Montreal)\" title=\"Victoria Bridge (Montreal)\" id=\"mwAXg\">Victoria Bridge</a> established Montreal as a major railway hub. The leaders of Montreal's business community had started to build their homes in the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Golden_Square_Mile\" title=\"Golden Square Mile\" id=\"mwAXk\">Golden Square Mile</a> from about 1850. By 1860, it was the largest municipality in <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./British_North_America\" title=\"British North America\" id=\"mwAXo\">British North America</a> and the undisputed economic and cultural centre of Canada.<sup about=\"#mwt422\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-ICAIS_66-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"ICAIS\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-ICAIS-66\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-ICAIS-66\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 66;\" id=\"mwAXs\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAXw\">[66]</span></a></sup><sup about=\"#mwt426\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-UNAC_67-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"UNAC\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-UNAC-67\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-UNAC-67\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 67;\" id=\"mwAX0\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAX4\">[67]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAX8\">In the 19th<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwAYA\"> </span>century, maintaining Montreal's drinking water became increasingly difficult with the rapid increase in population. A majority of the drinking water was still coming from the city's harbour, which was busy and heavily trafficked, leading to the deterioration of the water within. In the mid-1840s, the City of Montreal installed a water system that would pump water from the St. Lawrence and into <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Cistern\" title=\"Cistern\" id=\"mwAYE\">cisterns</a>. The cisterns would then be transported to the desired location. This was not the first water system of its type in Montreal, as there had been one in private ownership since 1801. In the middle of the 19th<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwAYI\"> </span>century, water distribution was carried out by \"fontainiers\". The fountainiers<link rel=\"mw:PageProp/Category\" href=\"./Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_clarification_from_February_2022\" about=\"#mwt430\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"Clarify\",\"href\":\"./Template:Clarify\"},\"params\":{\"date\":{\"wt\":\"February 2022\"},\"reason\":{\"wt\":\"Two different spellings - which is correct?\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAYM\"/><sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template \" style=\"margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;\" about=\"#mwt430\" id=\"mwAYQ\"><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\">[</span><i><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Wikipedia:Please_clarify\" title=\"Wikipedia:Please clarify\"><span title=\"Two different spellings - which is correct? (February 2022)\">clarification needed</span></a></i><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\">]</span></sup> would open and close water valves outside of buildings, as directed, all over the city. As they lacked modern plumbing systems it was impossible to connect all buildings at once and it also acted as a conservation method. However, the population was not finished rising — it rose from 58,000 in 1852 to 267,000 by 1901.<sup about=\"#mwt431\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-68\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-68\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-68\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 68;\" id=\"mwAYU\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAYY\">[68]</span></a></sup><sup about=\"#mwt432\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-69\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-69\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-69\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 69;\" id=\"mwAYc\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAYg\">[69]</span></a></sup><sup about=\"#mwt433\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-70\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-70\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-70\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 70;\" id=\"mwAYk\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAYo\">[70]</span></a></sup></p>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size mw-halign-left\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\" id=\"mwAYs\"><a href=\"./File:Incendie_Parlement_Montreal.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\" id=\"mwAYw\"><img resource=\"./File:Incendie_Parlement_Montreal.jpg\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Incendie_Parlement_Montreal.jpg/220px-Incendie_Parlement_Montreal.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" data-file-width=\"922\" data-file-height=\"615\" data-file-type=\"bitmap\" height=\"147\" width=\"220\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Incendie_Parlement_Montreal.jpg/330px-Incendie_Parlement_Montreal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Incendie_Parlement_Montreal.jpg/440px-Incendie_Parlement_Montreal.jpg 2x\" class=\"mw-file-element\" id=\"mwAY0\"/></a><figcaption id=\"mwAY4\">Political protests from <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Tories\" title=\"Tories\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAY8\">Tories</a> led to the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Burning_of_the_Parliament_Buildings_in_Montreal\" title=\"Burning of the Parliament Buildings in Montreal\" id=\"mwAZA\">burning of the Parliament Buildings in Montreal</a> in 1849.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mwAZE\">Montreal was the capital of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Province_of_Canada\" title=\"Province of Canada\" id=\"mwAZI\">Province of Canada</a> from 1844 to 1849, but lost its status when a <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Toryism#Canada\" title=\"Toryism\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAZM\">Tory</a> mob <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Burning_of_the_Parliament_Buildings_in_Montreal\" title=\"Burning of the Parliament Buildings in Montreal\" id=\"mwAZQ\">burnt down the Parliament building</a> to protest the passage of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Rebellion_Losses_Bill\" title=\"Rebellion Losses Bill\" id=\"mwAZU\">Rebellion Losses Bill</a>.<sup about=\"#mwt439\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-71\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-71\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-71\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 71;\" id=\"mwAZY\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAZc\">[71]</span></a></sup> Thereafter, the capital rotated between Quebec City and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Toronto\" title=\"Toronto\" id=\"mwAZg\">Toronto</a> until in 1857, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Queen_Victoria\" title=\"Queen Victoria\" id=\"mwAZk\">Queen Victoria</a> herself established <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Ottawa\" title=\"Ottawa\" id=\"mwAZo\">Ottawa</a> as the capital due to strategic reasons. The reasons were twofold. First, because it was located more in the interior of the Province of Canada, it was less susceptible to attack from the United States. Second, and perhaps more importantly, because it lay on the border between French and English Canada, Ottawa was seen as a compromise between Montreal, Toronto, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Kingston,_Ontario\" title=\"Kingston, Ontario\" id=\"mwAZs\">Kingston</a> and Quebec City, which were all vying to become the young nation's official capital. Ottawa retained the status as capital of Canada when the Province of Canada joined with <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Nova_Scotia\" title=\"Nova Scotia\" id=\"mwAZw\">Nova Scotia</a> and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./New_Brunswick\" title=\"New Brunswick\" id=\"mwAZ0\">New Brunswick</a> to form the Dominion of Canada in 1867.<link rel=\"mw:PageProp/Category\" href=\"./Category:All_articles_with_unsourced_statements\" about=\"#mwt435\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"citation needed\",\"href\":\"./Template:Citation_needed\"},\"params\":{\"date\":{\"wt\":\"May 2022\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAZ4\"/><link rel=\"mw:PageProp/Category\" href=\"./Category:Articles_with_unsourced_statements_from_May_2022\" about=\"#mwt435\"/><sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact\" style=\"white-space:nowrap;\" about=\"#mwt435\" id=\"mwAZ8\"><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\">[</span><i><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Wikipedia:Citation_needed\" title=\"Wikipedia:Citation needed\"><span title=\"This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)\">citation needed</span></a></i><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\">]</span></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAaA\">An <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Internment_camp\" title=\"Internment camp\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAaE\">internment camp</a> was set up at Immigration Hall in Montreal from August 1914 to November 1918.<sup about=\"#mwt444\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-72\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-72\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-72\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 72;\" id=\"mwAaI\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAaM\">[72]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAaQ\">After <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./World_War_I\" title=\"World War I\" id=\"mwAaU\">World War I</a>, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Prohibition\" title=\"Prohibition\" id=\"mwAaY\">prohibition</a> movement in the United States led to Montreal becoming a destination for Americans looking for <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Alcoholic_beverage\" title=\"Alcoholic beverage\" id=\"mwAac\">alcohol</a>.<sup about=\"#mwt450\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Telegraph_73-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Telegraph\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Telegraph-73\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Telegraph-73\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 73;\" id=\"mwAag\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAak\">[73]</span></a></sup> Unemployment remained high in the city and was exacerbated by the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Wall_Street_Crash_1929\" title=\"Wall Street Crash 1929\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAao\">Stock Market Crash of 1929</a> and the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Great_Depression\" title=\"Great Depression\" id=\"mwAas\">Great Depression</a>.<sup about=\"#mwt454\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-74\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-74\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-74\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 74;\" id=\"mwAaw\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAa0\">[74]</span></a></sup></p>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\" id=\"mwAa4\"><a href=\"./File:Anti-conscription_parade_at_Victoria_Square.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\" id=\"mwAa8\"><img resource=\"./File:Anti-conscription_parade_at_Victoria_Square.jpg\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Anti-conscription_parade_at_Victoria_Square.jpg/220px-Anti-conscription_parade_at_Victoria_Square.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" data-file-width=\"768\" data-file-height=\"601\" data-file-type=\"bitmap\" height=\"172\" width=\"220\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Anti-conscription_parade_at_Victoria_Square.jpg/330px-Anti-conscription_parade_at_Victoria_Square.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Anti-conscription_parade_at_Victoria_Square.jpg/440px-Anti-conscription_parade_at_Victoria_Square.jpg 2x\" class=\"mw-file-element\" id=\"mwAbA\"/></a><figcaption id=\"mwAbE\">An anti-<a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Conscription\" title=\"Conscription\" id=\"mwAbI\">conscription</a> rally in Montreal, 1917. During both <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./World_Wars\" title=\"World Wars\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAbM\">World Wars</a>, the city saw protest against the implementation of conscription.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mwAbQ\">During <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./World_War_II\" title=\"World War II\" id=\"mwAbU\">World War II</a>, Mayor <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Camillien_Houde\" title=\"Camillien Houde\" id=\"mwAbY\">Camillien Houde</a> protested against conscription and urged Montrealers to disobey the federal government's registry of all men and women.<sup about=\"#mwt461\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-MTAU_75-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"MTAU\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-MTAU-75\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-MTAU-75\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 75;\" id=\"mwAbc\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAbg\">[75]</span></a></sup> The federal government, part of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Allies_of_World_War_II\" title=\"Allies of World War II\" id=\"mwAbk\">Allied forces</a>, was furious over Houde's stand and held him in a prison camp until 1944.<sup about=\"#mwt465\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-76\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-76\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-76\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 76;\" id=\"mwAbo\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAbs\">[76]</span></a></sup> That year, the government decided to institute conscription to expand the armed forces and fight the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Axis_powers\" title=\"Axis powers\" id=\"mwAbw\">Axis powers</a>. (See <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Conscription_Crisis_of_1944\" title=\"Conscription Crisis of 1944\" id=\"mwAb0\">Conscription Crisis of 1944</a>.)<sup about=\"#mwt466\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-MTAU_75-1\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"MTAU\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-MTAU-75\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 75;\" id=\"mwAb4\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAb8\">[75]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAcA\">Montreal was the official residence of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Luxembourg\" title=\"Luxembourg\" id=\"mwAcE\">Luxembourg</a> royal family in exile during World War II.<sup about=\"#mwt471\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-77\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-77\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-77\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 77;\" id=\"mwAcI\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAcM\">[77]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAcQ\">By 1951, Montreal's population had surpassed one million.<sup about=\"#mwt478\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-78\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-78\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-78\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 78;\" id=\"mwAcU\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAcY\">[78]</span></a></sup> However, Toronto's growth had begun challenging Montreal's status as the economic capital of Canada. Indeed, the volume of stocks traded at the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Toronto_Stock_Exchange\" title=\"Toronto Stock Exchange\" id=\"mwAcc\">Toronto Stock Exchange</a> had already surpassed that traded at the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montreal_Stock_Exchange\" title=\"Montreal Stock Exchange\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAcg\">Montreal Stock Exchange</a> in the 1940s.<sup about=\"#mwt479\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-79\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-79\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-79\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 79;\" id=\"mwAck\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAco\">[79]</span></a></sup> The <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Saint_Lawrence_Seaway\" title=\"Saint Lawrence Seaway\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAcs\">Saint Lawrence Seaway</a> opened in 1959, allowing vessels to bypass Montreal. In time, this development led to the end of the city's economic dominance as businesses moved to other areas.<sup about=\"#mwt483\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-80\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-80\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-80\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 80;\" id=\"mwAcw\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAc0\">[80]</span></a></sup> During the 1960s, there was continued growth as Canada's tallest skyscrapers, new expressways and the subway system known as the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montreal_Metro\" title=\"Montreal Metro\" id=\"mwAc4\">Montreal Metro</a> were finished during this time. Montreal also held the World's Fair of 1967, better known as <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Expo67\" title=\"Expo67\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAc8\">Expo67</a>.</p>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size mw-halign-left\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\" id=\"mwAdA\"><a href=\"./File:Stephane_Prefontaine,_Sandra_Henderson_1976b.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\" id=\"mwAdE\"><img resource=\"./File:Stephane_Prefontaine,_Sandra_Henderson_1976b.jpg\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Stephane_Prefontaine%2C_Sandra_Henderson_1976b.jpg/170px-Stephane_Prefontaine%2C_Sandra_Henderson_1976b.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" data-file-width=\"700\" data-file-height=\"471\" data-file-type=\"bitmap\" height=\"114\" width=\"170\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Stephane_Prefontaine%2C_Sandra_Henderson_1976b.jpg/255px-Stephane_Prefontaine%2C_Sandra_Henderson_1976b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Stephane_Prefontaine%2C_Sandra_Henderson_1976b.jpg/340px-Stephane_Prefontaine%2C_Sandra_Henderson_1976b.jpg 2x\" class=\"mw-file-element\" id=\"mwAdI\"/></a><figcaption id=\"mwAdM\">Lighting of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Olympic_Torch\" title=\"Olympic Torch\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAdQ\">Olympic Torch</a> inside Montreal's <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Olympic_Stadium_(Montreal)\" title=\"Olympic Stadium (Montreal)\" id=\"mwAdU\">Olympic Stadium</a>. The city hosted the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./1976_Summer_Olympics\" title=\"1976 Summer Olympics\" id=\"mwAdY\">1976 Summer Olympics</a>.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mwAdc\">The 1970s ushered in a period of wide-ranging social and political changes, stemming largely from the concerns of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./French_Canadians\" title=\"French Canadians\" id=\"mwAdg\">French-speaking</a> majority about the conservation of their culture and language, given the traditional predominance of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./English_Canadians\" title=\"English Canadians\" id=\"mwAdk\">English Canadian</a> minority in the business arena.<sup about=\"#mwt490\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-81\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-81\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-81\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 81;\" id=\"mwAdo\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAds\">[81]</span></a></sup> The <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./October_Crisis\" title=\"October Crisis\" id=\"mwAdw\">October Crisis</a> and the 1976 election of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Parti_Québécois\" title=\"Parti Québécois\" id=\"mwAd0\">Parti Québécois</a>, which supported sovereign status for Quebec, resulted in the departure of many businesses and people from the city.<sup about=\"#mwt494\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-RoughGuide_82-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"RoughGuide\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-RoughGuide-82\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-RoughGuide-82\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 82;\" id=\"mwAd4\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAd8\">[82]</span></a></sup> In 1976, Montreal hosted the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./1976_Summer_Olympics\" title=\"1976 Summer Olympics\" id=\"mwAeA\">Summer Olympics</a>. While the event brought the city international prestige and attention, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Olympic_Stadium_(Montreal)\" title=\"Olympic Stadium (Montreal)\" id=\"mwAeE\">Olympic Stadium</a> built for the event resulted in massive debt for the city.<sup about=\"#mwt498\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-IOC_83-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"IOC\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-IOC-83\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-IOC-83\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 83;\" id=\"mwAeI\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAeM\">[83]</span></a></sup> During the 1980s and early 1990s, Montreal experienced a slower rate of economic growth than many other major Canadian cities. Montreal was the site of the 1989 <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./École_Polytechnique_massacre\" title=\"École Polytechnique massacre\" id=\"mwAeQ\">École Polytechnique massacre</a>, one of Canada's worst <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Mass_shooting\" title=\"Mass shooting\" id=\"mwAeU\">mass shootings</a>, where 25-year-old <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Marc_Lépine\" title=\"Marc Lépine\" id=\"mwAeY\">Marc Lépine</a> shot and killed 14 people, all of them women, and wounded 14 other people before shooting himself at <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Polytechnique_Montréal\" title=\"Polytechnique Montréal\" id=\"mwAec\">École Polytechnique</a>.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAeg\">Montreal was <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montreal_Merger\" title=\"Montreal Merger\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAek\">merged</a> with the 27 surrounding municipalities on the Island of Montreal on January 1, 2002, creating a unified city encompassing the entire island. There was substantial resistance from the suburbs to the merger, with the perception being that it was forced on the mostly English suburbs by the Parti Québécois. As expected, this move proved unpopular and several mergers were later rescinded. Several former municipalities, totalling 13% of the population of the island, voted to leave the unified city in separate <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Referendum\" title=\"Referendum\" id=\"mwAeo\">referendums</a> in June 2004. The demerger took place on January 1, 2006, leaving 15 municipalities on the island, including Montreal. Demerged municipalities remain affiliated with the city through an agglomeration council that collects taxes from them to pay for numerous shared services.<sup about=\"#mwt503\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Agglomeration_council_84-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Agglomeration council\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Agglomeration_council-84\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Agglomeration_council-84\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 84;\" id=\"mwAes\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAew\">[84]</span></a></sup> The 2002 mergers were not the first in the city's history. Montreal annexed 27 other cities, towns and villages beginning with <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Mercier–Hochelaga-Maisonneuve#History\" title=\"Mercier–Hochelaga-Maisonneuve\" id=\"mwAe0\">Hochelaga</a> in 1883, with the last prior to 2002 being <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Pointe-aux-Trembles\" title=\"Pointe-aux-Trembles\" id=\"mwAe4\">Pointe-aux-Trembles</a> in 1982.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAe8\">The 21st<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwAfA\"> </span>century has brought with it a revival of the city's economic and cultural landscape. The construction of new residential skyscrapers, two super-hospitals (the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Centre_hospitalier_de_l'Université_de_Montréal\" title=\"Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal\" id=\"mwAfE\">Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal</a> and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./McGill_University_Health_Centre\" title=\"McGill University Health Centre\" id=\"mwAfI\">McGill University Health Centre</a>), the creation of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quartier_des_Spectacles\" title=\"Quartier des Spectacles\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAfM\">Quartier des Spectacles</a>, reconstruction of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Turcot_Interchange\" title=\"Turcot Interchange\" id=\"mwAfQ\">Turcot Interchange</a>, reconfiguration of the Decarie and Dorval interchanges, construction of the new <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Réseau_express_métropolitain\" title=\"Réseau express métropolitain\" id=\"mwAfU\">Réseau express métropolitain</a>, gentrification of <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Griffintown\" title=\"Griffintown\" id=\"mwAfY\">Griffintown</a>, subway line extensions and the purchase of new subway cars, the complete revitalization and expansion of <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montréal–Trudeau_International_Airport\" title=\"Montréal–Trudeau International Airport\" id=\"mwAfc\">Trudeau International Airport</a>, the completion of <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Autoroute_30\" title=\"Quebec Autoroute 30\" id=\"mwAfg\">Quebec Autoroute 30</a>, the reconstruction of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Champlain_Bridge,_Montreal\" title=\"Champlain Bridge, Montreal\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAfk\">Champlain Bridge</a> and the construction of a new toll bridge to Laval are helping Montreal continue to grow.<link rel=\"mw:PageProp/Category\" href=\"./Category:All_articles_with_unsourced_statements\" about=\"#mwt504\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"Citation needed\",\"href\":\"./Template:Citation_needed\"},\"params\":{\"date\":{\"wt\":\"May 2015\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAfo\"/><link rel=\"mw:PageProp/Category\" href=\"./Category:Articles_with_unsourced_statements_from_May_2015\" about=\"#mwt504\"/><sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact\" style=\"white-space:nowrap;\" about=\"#mwt504\" id=\"mwAfs\"><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\">[</span><i><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Wikipedia:Citation_needed\" title=\"Wikipedia:Citation needed\"><span title=\"This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2015)\">citation needed</span></a></i><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\">]</span></sup></p>\n\n</section></section><section data-mw-section-id=\"7\" id=\"mwAfw\"><h2 id=\"Geography\">Geography</h2>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096\" about=\"#mwt505\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"Main\",\"href\":\"./Template:Main\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"Geography of Montreal\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAf0\"/><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\" about=\"#mwt505\" id=\"mwAf4\">Main article: <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Geography_of_Montreal\" title=\"Geography of Montreal\">Geography of Montreal</a></div>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\" id=\"mwAf8\"><a href=\"./File:Montreal_Canada_from_ISS014.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\" id=\"mwAgA\"><img resource=\"./File:Montreal_Canada_from_ISS014.jpg\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Montreal_Canada_from_ISS014.jpg/220px-Montreal_Canada_from_ISS014.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" data-file-width=\"3032\" data-file-height=\"2008\" data-file-type=\"bitmap\" height=\"146\" width=\"220\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Montreal_Canada_from_ISS014.jpg/330px-Montreal_Canada_from_ISS014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Montreal_Canada_from_ISS014.jpg/440px-Montreal_Canada_from_ISS014.jpg 2x\" class=\"mw-file-element\" id=\"mwAgE\"/></a><figcaption id=\"mwAgI\">The <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Island_of_Montreal\" title=\"Island of Montreal\" id=\"mwAgM\">island of Montreal</a> at the confluence of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Saint_Lawrence_River\" title=\"Saint Lawrence River\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAgQ\">Saint Lawrence</a> and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Ottawa_River\" title=\"Ottawa River\" id=\"mwAgU\">Ottawa</a> rivers.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mwAgY\">Montreal is in the southwest of the province of Quebec. The city covers most of the Island of Montreal at the confluence of the Saint Lawrence and Ottawa Rivers. The port of Montreal lies at one end of the Saint Lawrence Seaway, the river gateway that stretches from the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Great_Lakes\" title=\"Great Lakes\" id=\"mwAgc\">Great Lakes</a> to the Atlantic.<sup about=\"#mwt514\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Great_Canadian_Rivers_85-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Great Canadian Rivers\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Great_Canadian_Rivers-85\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Great_Canadian_Rivers-85\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 85;\" id=\"mwAgg\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAgk\">[85]</span></a></sup> Montreal is defined by its location between the Saint Lawrence river to its south and the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Rivière_des_Prairies\" title=\"Rivière des Prairies\" id=\"mwAgo\">Rivière des Prairies</a> to its north. The city is named after the most prominent geographical feature on the island, a three-head hill called Mount Royal, topped at <span about=\"#mwt510\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"convert\",\"href\":\"./Template:Convert\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"232\"},\"2\":{\"wt\":\"m\"},\"abbr\":{\"wt\":\"on\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAgs\">232</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt510\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt510\">m (761</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt510\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt510\">ft)</span> <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Above_mean_sea_level\" title=\"Above mean sea level\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAgw\">above sea level</a>.<sup about=\"#mwt518\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Natural_Resources_Canada_86-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Natural Resources Canada\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Natural_Resources_Canada-86\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Natural_Resources_Canada-86\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 86;\" id=\"mwAg0\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAg4\">[86]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAg8\">Montreal is at the centre of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Greater_Montreal\" title=\"Greater Montreal\" id=\"mwAhA\">Montreal Metropolitan Community</a>, and is bordered by the city of <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Laval,_Quebec\" title=\"Laval, Quebec\" id=\"mwAhE\">Laval</a> to the north; <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Longueuil\" title=\"Longueuil\" id=\"mwAhI\">Longueuil</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Saint-Lambert,_Quebec\" title=\"Saint-Lambert, Quebec\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAhM\">Saint-Lambert</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Brossard\" title=\"Brossard\" id=\"mwAhQ\">Brossard</a>, and other municipalities to the south; <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Repentigny,_Quebec\" title=\"Repentigny, Quebec\" id=\"mwAhU\">Repentigny</a> to the east and the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./West_Island\" title=\"West Island\" id=\"mwAhY\">West Island</a> municipalities to the west. The <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./English_language\" title=\"English language\" id=\"mwAhc\">anglophone</a> enclaves of <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Westmount,_Quebec\" title=\"Westmount, Quebec\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAhg\">Westmount</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montreal_West,_Quebec\" title=\"Montreal West, Quebec\" id=\"mwAhk\">Montreal West</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Hampstead,_Quebec\" title=\"Hampstead, Quebec\" id=\"mwAho\">Hampstead</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Côte_Saint-Luc\" title=\"Côte Saint-Luc\" id=\"mwAhs\">Côte Saint-Luc</a>, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Mount_Royal,_Quebec\" title=\"Mount Royal, Quebec\" id=\"mwAhw\">Town of Mount Royal</a> and the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Francophone\" title=\"Francophone\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAh0\">francophone</a> enclave <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montréal-Est,_Quebec\" title=\"Montréal-Est, Quebec\" id=\"mwAh4\">Montreal East</a> are all surrounded by Montreal.<sup about=\"#mwt523\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-City_Map_87-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"City Map\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-City_Map-87\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-City_Map-87\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;\" id=\"mwAh8\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAiA\">[87]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<section data-mw-section-id=\"8\" id=\"mwAiE\"><h3 id=\"Climate\">Climate</h3>\n<p id=\"mwAiI\">Montreal is classified as a <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Warm-summer_humid_continental_climate\" title=\"Warm-summer humid continental climate\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAiM\">warm-summer humid continental climate</a> (<a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Köppen_climate_classification\" title=\"Köppen climate classification\" id=\"mwAiQ\">Köppen climate classification</a>: Dfb).<sup about=\"#mwt529\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Köppen_88-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Köppen\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Köppen-88\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Köppen-88\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 88;\" id=\"mwAiU\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAiY\">[88]</span></a></sup><sup about=\"#mwt533\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Climate-Data.org_89-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Climate-Data.org\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Climate-Data.org-89\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Climate-Data.org-89\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 89;\" id=\"mwAic\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAig\">[89]</span></a></sup>\nSummers are warm to hot and humid with a daily maximum average of <span about=\"#mwt534\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"convert\",\"href\":\"./Template:Convert\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"26\"},\"2\":{\"wt\":\"to\"},\"3\":{\"wt\":\"27\"},\"4\":{\"wt\":\"C\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAik\">26 to 27</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt534\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt534\">°C (79 to 81</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt534\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt534\">°F)</span> in July; temperatures in excess of <span about=\"#mwt535\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"convert\",\"href\":\"./Template:Convert\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"30\"},\"2\":{\"wt\":\"C\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAio\">30</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt535\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt535\">°C (86</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt535\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt535\">°F)</span> are common. Conversely, cold fronts can bring crisp, drier and windy weather in the early and later parts of summer.</p>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\" id=\"mwAis\"><a href=\"./File:Montreal_Winter_Snowing.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\" id=\"mwAiw\"><img resource=\"./File:Montreal_Winter_Snowing.jpg\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Montreal_Winter_Snowing.jpg/220px-Montreal_Winter_Snowing.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" data-file-width=\"3840\" data-file-height=\"2160\" data-file-type=\"bitmap\" height=\"124\" width=\"220\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Montreal_Winter_Snowing.jpg/330px-Montreal_Winter_Snowing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Montreal_Winter_Snowing.jpg/440px-Montreal_Winter_Snowing.jpg 2x\" class=\"mw-file-element\" id=\"mwAi0\"/></a><figcaption id=\"mwAi4\">Winters in Montreal bring cold, snowy, windy, and at times, icy weather.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mwAi8\">Winter brings cold, snowy, windy, and, at times, icy weather, with a daily average ranging from <span about=\"#mwt538\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"convert\",\"href\":\"./Template:Convert\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"-10.5\"},\"2\":{\"wt\":\"to\"},\"3\":{\"wt\":\"-9\"},\"4\":{\"wt\":\"C\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAjA\">−10.5 to −9</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt538\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt538\">°C (13.1 to 15.8</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt538\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt538\">°F)</span> in January. However, some winter days rise above freezing, allowing for rain on an average of 4 days in January and February each. Usually, snow covering some or all bare ground lasts on average from the first or second week of December until the last week of March.<sup about=\"#mwt543\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-CurrentResults.com_90-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"CurrentResults.com\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-CurrentResults.com-90\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-CurrentResults.com-90\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 90;\" id=\"mwAjE\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAjI\">[90]</span></a></sup> While the air temperature does not fall below <span about=\"#mwt539\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"convert\",\"href\":\"./Template:Convert\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"-30\"},\"2\":{\"wt\":\"C\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAjM\">−30</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt539\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt539\">°C (−22</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt539\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt539\">°F)</span> every year,<sup about=\"#mwt547\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-Montreal_Weather_Data_91-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"Montreal Weather Data\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Montreal_Weather_Data-91\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-Montreal_Weather_Data-91\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 91;\" id=\"mwAjQ\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAjU\">[91]</span></a></sup> the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Wind_chill\" title=\"Wind chill\" id=\"mwAjY\">wind chill</a> often makes the temperature feel this low to exposed skin.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAjc\">Spring and fall are pleasantly mild but prone to drastic temperature changes; spring even more so than fall.<sup about=\"#mwt552\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-92\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-92\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-92\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 92;\" id=\"mwAjg\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAjk\">[92]</span></a></sup> Late season heat waves as well as \"<a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Indian_summer\" title=\"Indian summer\" id=\"mwAjo\">Indian summers</a>\" are possible. Early and late season snow storms can occur in November and March, and more rarely in April. Montreal is generally snow free from late April to late October. However, snow can fall in early to mid-October as well as early to mid-May on rare occasions.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAjs\">The lowest temperature in Environment Canada's books was <span about=\"#mwt554\" id=\"mwAmE\">Many colonial era buildings can be found in <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Old_Montreal\" title=\"Old Montreal\" id=\"mwAmI\">Old Montreal</a> with several dating as far back as the late 17th century.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mwAmM\">For over a century and a half, Montreal was the industrial and financial centre of Canada.<sup about=\"#mwt622\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-103\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-103\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-103\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 103;\" id=\"mwAmQ\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAmU\">[103]</span></a></sup> This legacy has left a variety of buildings including factories, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Grain_elevators\" title=\"Grain elevators\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAmY\">elevators</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Warehouses\" title=\"Warehouses\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAmc\">warehouses</a>, mills, and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Refineries\" title=\"Refineries\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAmg\">refineries</a>, that today provide an invaluable insight into the city's history, especially in the downtown area and the Old Port area. There are 50 <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./List_of_National_Historic_Sites_of_Canada_in_Montreal\" title=\"List of National Historic Sites of Canada in Montreal\" id=\"mwAmk\">National Historic Sites of Canada</a>, more than any other city.<sup about=\"#mwt627\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-104\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-104\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-104\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 104;\" id=\"mwAmo\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAms\">[104]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAmw\">Some of the city's earliest still-standing buildings date back to the late 17th and early 18th centuries. Although most are clustered around the Old Montreal area, such as the Sulpician Seminary adjacent to Notre Dame Basilica that dates back to 1687, and Château Ramezay, which was built in 1705, examples of early colonial architecture are dotted throughout the city. Situated in Lachine, the Le Ber-Le Moyne House is the oldest complete building in the city, built between 1669 and 1671. In Point St. Charles visitors can see the Maison Saint-Gabriel, which can trace its history back to 1698.<sup about=\"#mwt633\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-105\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-105\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-105\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 105;\" id=\"mwAm0\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAm4\">[105]</span></a></sup> There are many historic buildings in Old Montreal in their original form: <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Notre-Dame_de_Montréal_Basilica\" title=\"Notre-Dame de Montréal Basilica\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwAm8\">Notre Dame of Montreal Basilica</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Bonsecours_Market\" title=\"Bonsecours Market\" id=\"mwAnA\">Bonsecours Market</a>, and the 19th‑century headquarters of all major Canadian banks on <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Saint_Jacques_Street\" title=\"Saint Jacques Street\" id=\"mwAnE\">St. James Street</a> (French: Rue Saint Jacques). Montreal's earliest buildings are characterized by their uniquely French influence and grey stone construction.<sup about=\"#mwt637\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-106\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-106\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-106\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 106;\" id=\"mwAnI\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAnM\">[106]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size mw-halign-left\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\" id=\"mwAn4\">Art Deco</a> <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Université_de_Montréal\" title=\"Université de Montréal\" id=\"mwAn8\">Université de Montréal</a> main building, the landmark <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Place_Ville_Marie\" title=\"Place Ville Marie\" id=\"mwAoA\">Place Ville Marie</a> office tower, the controversial Olympic Stadium and surrounding structures, are but a few notable examples of the city's 20th-century architecture. Pavilions designed for the 1967 International and Universal Exposition, popularly known as Expo<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwAoE\"> </span>67, featured a wide range of architectural designs. Though most pavilions were temporary structures, several have become landmarks, including Buckminster Fuller's <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Geodesic_dome\" title=\"Geodesic dome\" id=\"mwAoI\">geodesic dome</a> U.S.<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwAoM\"> </span>Pavilion, now the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montreal_Biosphere\" title=\"Montreal Biosphere\" id=\"mwAoQ\">Montreal Biosphere</a>, and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Moshe_Safdie\" title=\"Moshe Safdie\" id=\"mwAoU\">Moshe Safdie</a>'s striking Habitat<span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" id=\"mwAoY\"> </span>67 apartment complex.<link rel=\"mw:PageProp/Category\" href=\"./Category:All_articles_with_unsourced_statements\" about=\"#mwt638\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"citation needed\",\"href\":\"./Template:Citation_needed\"},\"params\":{\"date\":{\"wt\":\"May 2022\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwAoc\"/><link rel=\"mw:PageProp/Category\" href=\"./Category:Articles_with_unsourced_statements_from_May_2022\" about=\"#mwt638\"/><sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact\" style=\"white-space:nowrap;\" about=\"#mwt638\" id=\"mwAog\"><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\">[</span><i><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Wikipedia:Citation_needed\" title=\"Wikipedia:Citation needed\"><span title=\"This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)\">citation needed</span></a></i><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\">]</span></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAok\">The Montreal Metro has public artwork by some of the biggest names in <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Culture_of_Quebec\" title=\"Culture of Quebec\" id=\"mwAoo\">Quebec culture</a>.<sup about=\"#mwt643\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-107\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-107\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-107\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 107;\" id=\"mwAos\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwAow\">[107]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwAo0\">In 2006 Montreal was named a UNESCO City of Design, one of only three design capitals of the world (the others being <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Berlin\" title=\"Berlin\" id=\"mwAo4\">Berlin</a> and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Buenos_Aires\" title=\"Buenos Aires\" id=\"mwAo8\">Buenos Aires</a>).<sup about=\"#mwt647\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-UNESCO_29-1\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"UNESCO\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-UNESCO-29\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 29;\" id=\"mwApA\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwApE\">[29]</span></a></sup> This distinguished title recognizes Montreal's design community. Since 2005 the city has been home for the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./International_Council_of_Graphic_Design_Associations\" title=\"International Council of Graphic Design Associations\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwApI\">International Council of Graphic Design Associations</a> (Icograda);<sup about=\"#mwt651\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-ICOGRADA_108-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"ICOGRADA\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-ICOGRADA-108\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-ICOGRADA-108\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 108;\" id=\"mwApM\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwApQ\">[108]</span></a></sup> the International Design Alliance (IDA).<sup about=\"#mwt655\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-BNET_109-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"BNET\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-BNET-109\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-BNET-109\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 109;\" id=\"mwApU\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwApY\">[109]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwApc\">The <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Underground_City,_Montreal\" title=\"Underground City, Montreal\" id=\"mwApg\">Underground City</a> (officially RÉSO), an important tourist attraction, is an underground network connecting shopping centres, pedestrian thoroughfares, universities, hotels,
