title=\"Service de police de la Ville de Montréal\">Service de police de la Ville de Montréal</a></div>\n\n<p id=\"mwBuo\">Law enforcement on the island itself is provided by the <i id=\"mwBus\"><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./SPVM\" title=\"SPVM\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwBuw\">Service de Police de la Ville de Montréal</a>,</i> or the SPVM for short.</p>\n\n</section><section data-mw-section-id=\"24\" id=\"mwBu0\"><h2 id=\"Crime\">Crime</h2>\n<p id=\"mwBu4\">Since 1975, when Montreal's homicide rate peaked at around 10.3 per 100,000 people with a total of 112 murders, the overall crime rate in Montreal has declined, with a few notable exceptions, reaching a minimum in 2016 with 23 murders.<sup about=\"#mwt1337\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-217\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-217\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-217\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 212;\" id=\"mwBu8\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwBvA\">[212]</span></a></sup><sup about=\"#mwt1341\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-montreal.ctvnews.ca_218-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"montreal.ctvnews.ca\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-montreal.ctvnews.ca-218\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-montreal.ctvnews.ca-218\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 213;\" id=\"mwBvE\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwBvI\">[213]</span></a></sup> Sex crimes have increased 14.5 per cent between 2015 and 2016 and fraud cases have increased by 13 per cent over the same period.<sup about=\"#mwt1342\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-montreal.ctvnews.ca_218-1\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"montreal.ctvnews.ca\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-montreal.ctvnews.ca-218\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 213;\" id=\"mwBvM\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwBvQ\">[213]</span></a></sup> The major criminal organizations active in Montreal are the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Rizzuto_crime_family\" title=\"Rizzuto crime family\" id=\"mwBvU\">Rizzuto crime family</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Hells_Angels\" title=\"Hells Angels\" id=\"mwBvY\">Hells Angels</a> and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./West_End_Gang\" title=\"West End Gang\" id=\"mwBvc\">West End Gang</a>. However, in the 2020s, the city has seen an increase in overall crime, with a notable increase in homicides. 25 homicides were reported in 2020 which matched the number reported in 2019. The next year saw a 48% increase in murders with a total of 37 in 2021, giving the city a homicide rate of around 2.1 per 100,000 people. The Montreal Police Annual Report for 2021 showed that there were 144 shootings across the city, or an average of one shooting every 2.5 days. In comparison, there were 71 shootings recorded the year before.<sup about=\"#mwt1346\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-219\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-219\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-219\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 214;\" id=\"mwBvg\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwBvk\">[214]</span></a></sup> 2022 saw another 10.8% increase in homicides, with a total of 41 being reported (giving a slightly higher homicide rate of 2.3 per 100,000 people), the highest number since 2007, when there were 42.<sup about=\"#mwt1350\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-220\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-220\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-220\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 215;\" id=\"mwBvo\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwBvs\">[215]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n</section><section data-mw-section-id=\"25\" id=\"mwBvw\"><h2 id=\"Education\">Education</h2>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096\" about=\"#mwt1351\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"Main\",\"href\":\"./Template:Main\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"Education in Montreal\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwBv0\"/><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\" about=\"#mwt1351\" id=\"mwBv4\">Main article: <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Education_in_Montreal\" title=\"Education in Montreal\">Education in Montreal</a></div>\n<p id=\"mwBv8\">The <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Education_in_Quebec\" title=\"Education in Quebec\" id=\"mwBwA\">education system in Quebec</a> is different from other systems in North America. Between high school (which ends at grade 11) and university, students must go through an additional school called <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./CEGEP\" title=\"CEGEP\" id=\"mwBwE\">CEGEP</a>. CEGEPs offer pre-university (2-years) and technical (3-years) programs. In Montreal, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./List_of_CEGEPs\" title=\"List of CEGEPs\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwBwI\">seventeen CEGEPs</a> offer courses in French and five in English.</p>\n\n<p href=\"./File:Montreal_autoroute.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\" id=\"mwB28\"><img resource=\"./File:Montreal_autoroute.jpg\" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Montreal_autoroute.jpg/440px-Montreal_autoroute.jpg 2x\" class=\"mw-file-element\" id=\"mwB3A\"/></a><figcaption id=\"mwB3E\">Montreal is a hub for Quebec's <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Autoroutes_of_Quebec\" title=\"Autoroutes of Quebec\" id=\"mwB3I\">autoroute</a> system of <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Controlled-access_highway\" title=\"Controlled-access highway\" id=\"mwB3M\">controlled-access highways</a>.</figcaption></figure>\n<p id=\"mwB3Q\">Like many major cities, Montreal has a problem with vehicular traffic congestion. Commuting traffic from the cities and towns in the West Island (such as <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Dollard-des-Ormeaux\" title=\"Dollard-des-Ormeaux\" id=\"mwB3U\">Dollard-des-Ormeaux</a> and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Pointe-Claire\" title=\"Pointe-Claire\" id=\"mwB3Y\">Pointe-Claire</a>) is compounded by commuters entering the city that use twenty-four road crossings from numerous off-island suburbs on the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./North_Shore_(Laval)\" title=\"North Shore (Laval)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwB3c\">North</a> and South Shores. The width of the Saint Lawrence River has made the construction of fixed links to the south shore expensive and difficult. There are presently four road bridges (including two of the country's busiest) along with one bridge-tunnel, two railway bridges, and a metro line. The far narrower Rivière des Prairies to the city's north, separating Montreal from Laval, is spanned by nine road bridges (seven to the city of Laval and two that span directly to the north shore) and a Metro line.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwB3g\">The island of Montreal is a hub for the Quebec <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Autoroute_(Quebec)\" title=\"Autoroute (Quebec)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwB3k\">Autoroute</a> system, and is served by Quebec Autoroutes <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Autoroute_10\" title=\"Quebec Autoroute 10\" id=\"mwB3o\">A-10</a> (known as the Bonaventure Expressway on the island of Montreal), <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Autoroute_15\" title=\"Quebec Autoroute 15\" id=\"mwB3s\">A-15</a> (aka the Décarie Expressway south of the A-40 and the Laurentian Autoroute to the north of it), <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Autoroute_13\" title=\"Quebec Autoroute 13\" id=\"mwB3w\">A-13</a> (aka Chomedey Autoroute), <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Autoroute_20\" title=\"Quebec Autoroute 20\" id=\"mwB30\">A-20</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Autoroute_25\" title=\"Quebec Autoroute 25\" id=\"mwB34\">A-25</a>, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Autoroute_40\" title=\"Quebec Autoroute 40\" id=\"mwB38\">A-40</a> (part of the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Trans-Canada_Highway\" title=\"Trans-Canada Highway\" id=\"mwB4A\">Trans-Canada Highway</a> system, and known as \"The Metropolitan\" or simply \"The Met\" in its elevated mid-town section), <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Autoroute_520\" title=\"Quebec Autoroute 520\" id=\"mwB4E\">A-520</a> and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Route_136_(Montreal)\" title=\"Quebec Route 136 (Montreal)\" id=\"mwB4I\">R-136</a> (aka the Ville-Marie Autoroute). Many of these Autoroutes are frequently congested at <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Rush_hour\" title=\"Rush hour\" id=\"mwB4M\">rush hour</a>.<sup about=\"#mwt1416\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-epomm_232-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"epomm\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-epomm-232\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-epomm-232\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 227;\" id=\"mwB4Q\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB4U\">[227]</span></a></sup> However, in recent years, the government has acknowledged this problem and is working on long-term solutions to alleviate the congestion. One such example is the extension of <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Autoroute_30\" title=\"Quebec Autoroute 30\" id=\"mwB4Y\">Quebec Autoroute 30</a> on Montreal's south shore, which will be a <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Bypass_(road)\" title=\"Bypass (road)\" id=\"mwB4c\">bypass</a> for trucks and intercity traffic.<sup about=\"#mwt1420\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-TransportsQuebec_233-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"TransportsQuebec\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-TransportsQuebec-233\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-TransportsQuebec-233\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 228;\" id=\"mwB4g\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB4k\">[228]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<section data-mw-section-id=\"29\" id=\"mwB4o\"><h3 id=\"Société_de_transport_de_Montréal\"><span id=\"Soci.C3.A9t.C3.A9_de_transport_de_Montr.C3.A9al\" typeof=\"mw:FallbackId\"></span>Société de transport de Montréal</h3>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\" id=\"mwB4s\"><a href=\"./File:Métro_Acadie.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\" id=\"mwB4w\"><img resource=\"./File:Métro_Acadie.jpg\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/M%C3%A9tro_Acadie.jpg/220px-M%C3%A9tro_Acadie.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" data-file-width=\"3872\" data-file-height=\"2592\" data-file-type=\"bitmap\" height=\"147\" width=\"220\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/M%C3%A9tro_Acadie.jpg/330px-M%C3%A9tro_Acadie.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/M%C3%A9tro_Acadie.jpg/440px-M%C3%A9tro_Acadie.jpg 2x\" class=\"mw-file-element\" id=\"mwB40\"/></a><figcaption id=\"mwB44\">A train departs from <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Acadie_station\" title=\"Acadie station\" id=\"mwB48\">Acadie station</a>. The <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montreal_Metro\" title=\"Montreal Metro\" id=\"mwB5A\">Montreal Metro</a> has <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./List_of_Montreal_Metro_stations\" title=\"List of Montreal Metro stations\" id=\"mwB5E\">68 stations</a> and four lines.</figcaption></figure>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096\" about=\"#mwt1421\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"Main\",\"href\":\"./Template:Main\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"Société de transport de Montréal\"},\"2\":{\"wt\":\"Montreal Metro\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwB5I\"/><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\" about=\"#mwt1421\" id=\"mwB5M\">Main articles: <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Société_de_transport_de_Montréal\" title=\"Société de transport de Montréal\">Société de transport de Montréal</a> and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Montreal_Metro\" title=\"Montreal Metro\">Montreal Metro</a></div>\n<p id=\"mwB5Q\">Public local transport is served by a network of buses, subways, and commuter trains that extend across and off the island. The subway and bus system are operated by STM (<i id=\"mwB5U\">Société de transport de Montréal</i>, “Montreal Transit Company”). The <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./List_of_Montreal_bus_routes\" title=\"List of Montreal bus routes\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwB5Y\">STM bus network</a> consists of 203 daytime and 23 night time routes. STM bus routes serve 1,347,900 passengers on an average weekday in 2010.<sup about=\"#mwt1429\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-apta.com_234-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"apta.com\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-apta.com-234\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-apta.com-234\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 229;\" id=\"mwB5c\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB5g\">[229]</span></a></sup> It also provides adapted transport and wheelchair-accessible buses.<sup about=\"#mwt1433\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-235\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-235\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-235\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 230;\" id=\"mwB5k\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB5o\">[230]</span></a></sup> The STM won the award of Outstanding Public Transit System in North America by the APTA in 2010. It was the first time a Canadian company won this prize.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwB5s\">The Metro was inaugurated in 1966 and has 68 stations on four lines.<sup about=\"#mwt1442\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-236\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-236\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-236\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 231;\" id=\"mwB5w\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB50\">[231]</span></a></sup> Total daily passengers is 1,050,800 passengers on an average weekday (as of Q1 2010).<sup about=\"#mwt1443\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-apta.com_234-1\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"apta.com\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-apta.com-234\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 229;\" id=\"mwB54\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB58\">[229]</span></a></sup> Each station was designed by different architects with individual themes and features original artwork, and the trains run on rubber tires, making the system quieter than most.<sup about=\"#mwt1447\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-237\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-237\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-237\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 232;\" id=\"mwB6A\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB6E\">[232]</span></a></sup> The project was initiated by Montreal Mayor <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Jean_Drapeau\" title=\"Jean Drapeau\" id=\"mwB6I\">Jean Drapeau</a>, who later brought the Summer Olympic Games to Montreal in 1976. The Metro system has long had a station on the South Shore in <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Longueuil,_Quebec\" title=\"Longueuil, Quebec\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwB6M\">Longueuil</a>, and in 2007 was extended to the city of Laval, north of Montreal, with three new stations.<sup about=\"#mwt1451\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-238\" rel=\"dc:references\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 249;\" id=\"mwB-s\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB-w\">[249]</span></a></sup> Its corporate headquarters occupied <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Windsor_Station_(Montreal)\" title=\"Windsor Station (Montreal)\" id=\"mwB-0\">Windsor Station</a> at 910 <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Peel_Street,_Montreal\" title=\"Peel Street, Montreal\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwB-4\">Peel Street</a> until 1995, when it moved to <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Calgary\" title=\"Calgary\" id=\"mwB-8\">Calgary</a>, Alberta.<sup about=\"#mwt1533\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-CE-CP_150-1\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"CE-CP\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-CE-CP-150\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 145;\" id=\"mwB_A\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB_E\">[145]</span></a></sup> With the Port of Montreal kept open year-round by icebreakers, lines to Eastern Canada became surplus, and now Montreal is the eastern and intermodal freight terminus of CPR's successor company, <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Canadian_Pacific_Kansas_City\" title=\"Canadian Pacific Kansas City\" id=\"mwB_I\">Canadian Pacific Kansas City</a> (CPKC).<sup about=\"#mwt1537\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-CP-Map_255-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"CP-Map\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-CP-Map-255\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-CP-Map-255\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 250;\" id=\"mwB_M\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwB_Q\">[250]</span></a></sup> CPKC connects at Montreal with the Port of Montreal, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Delaware_and_Hudson_Railway\" title=\"Delaware and Hudson Railway\" id=\"mwB_U\">Delaware and Hudson Railway</a> to New York, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Quebec_Gatineau_Railway\" title=\"Quebec Gatineau Railway\" id=\"mwB_Y\">Quebec Gatineau Railway</a> to Quebec City and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Buckingham,_Quebec\" title=\"Buckingham, Quebec\" id=\"mwB_c\">Buckingham</a>, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Central_Maine_and_Quebec_Railway\" title=\"Central Maine and Quebec Railway\" class=\"mw-redirect\" id=\"mwB_g\">Central Maine and Quebec Railway</a> to Halifax, and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Canadian_National_Railway\" title=\"Canadian National Railway\" id=\"mwB_k\">Canadian National Railway</a> (CN). The CPR's flagship train, <i id=\"mwB_o\"><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./The_Canadian\" title=\"The Canadian\" id=\"mwB_s\">The Canadian</a></i>, ran daily from Windsor Station to <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Vancouver\" title=\"Vancouver\" id=\"mwB_w\">Vancouver</a>, but in 1978 all passenger services were transferred to Via. Since 1990, <i id=\"mwB_0\">The Canadian</i> has terminated in Toronto instead of in Montreal.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwB_4\">Montreal-based CN was formed in 1919 by the Canadian government following a series of country-wide rail bankruptcies. It was formed from the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Grand_Trunk_Railway\" title=\"Grand Trunk Railway\" id=\"mwB_8\">Grand Trunk</a>, Midland and <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Canadian_Northern_Railway\" title=\"Canadian Northern Railway\" id=\"mwCAA\">Canadian Northern Railways</a>, and has risen to become CPR's chief rival in freight carriage in Canada.<sup about=\"#mwt1543\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-CN-History_256-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"CN-History\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-CN-History-256\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-CN-History-256\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 251;\" id=\"mwCAE\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwCAI\">[251]</span></a></sup> Like the CPR, CN divested itself of passenger services in favour of Via.<sup about=\"#mwt1547\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-CN-Hist2_257-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"CN-Hist2\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-CN-Hist2-257\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-CN-Hist2-257\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 252;\" id=\"mwCAM\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwCAQ\">[252]</span></a></sup> CN's flagship train, the <i id=\"mwCAU\"><a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Super_Continental\" title=\"Super Continental\" id=\"mwCAY\">Super Continental</a></i>, ran daily from Central Station to Vancouver and subsequently became a Via train in 1978. It was eliminated in 1990 in favour of rerouting <i id=\"mwCAc\">The Canadian</i>.</p>\n\n<p id=\"mwCAg\">The commuter rail system is managed and operated by <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Exo_(public_transit)\" title=\"Exo (public transit)\" id=\"mwCAk\">Exo</a>, and reaches the outlying areas of Greater Montreal with six lines. It carried an average of 79,000 daily passengers in 2014, making it the seventh busiest in North America following New York, Chicago, Toronto, Boston, Philadelphia, and Mexico City.<sup about=\"#mwt1552\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-EMTA_258-0\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{\"name\":\"EMTA\"},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-EMTA-258\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-EMTA-258\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 253;\" id=\"mwCAo\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwCAs\">[253]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n<p id=\"mwCAw\">On April 22, 2016, the forthcoming automated <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Rapid_transit\" title=\"Rapid transit\" id=\"mwCA0\">rapid transit</a> system, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Réseau_express_métropolitain\" title=\"Réseau express métropolitain\" id=\"mwCA4\">Réseau express métropolitain</a> (REM), was unveiled. Groundbreaking occurred April 12, 2018, and construction of the <span about=\"#mwt1554\" typeof=\"mw:Transclusion\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"Convert\",\"href\":\"./Template:Convert\"},\"params\":{\"1\":{\"wt\":\"67\"},\"2\":{\"wt\":\"km\"},\"3\":{\"wt\":\"mi\"},\"adj\":{\"wt\":\"mid\"},\"4\":{\"wt\":\"-long\"}},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwCA8\">67-kilometre-long (42</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt1554\"> </span><span about=\"#mwt1554\">mi)</span> network<span typeof=\"mw:Transclusion mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt1555\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"snd\",\"href\":\"./Template:Snd\"},\"params\":{},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwCBA\"> </span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt1555\">–</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt1555\"> </span>consisting of three branches, 26 stations, and the conversion of the region's busiest commuter railway<span typeof=\"mw:Transclusion mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt1556\" data-mw='{\"parts\":[{\"template\":{\"target\":{\"wt\":\"snd\",\"href\":\"./Template:Snd\"},\"params\":{},\"i\":0}}]}' id=\"mwCBE\"> </span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt1556\">–</span><span typeof=\"mw:Entity\" about=\"#mwt1556\"> </span>commenced the following month. To be opened in three phases as of 2022, the REM will be completed by mid-2024, becoming the fourth largest automated rapid transit network after the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Dubai_Metro\" title=\"Dubai Metro\" id=\"mwCBI\">Dubai Metro</a>, the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Mass_Rapid_Transit_(Singapore)\" title=\"Mass Rapid Transit (Singapore)\" id=\"mwCBM\">Singapore Mass Rapid Transit</a>, and the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./SkyTrain_(Vancouver)\" title=\"SkyTrain (Vancouver)\" id=\"mwCBQ\">Vancouver SkyTrain</a>. Most of it will be financed by pension fund manager Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec (CDPQ Infra).<sup about=\"#mwt1560\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-259\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-259\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-259\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 254;\" id=\"mwCBU\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwCBY\">[254]</span></a></sup></p>\n\n</section><section data-mw-section-id=\"32\" id=\"mwCBc\"><h3 id=\"Bike_Share_Program\">Bike Share data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-260\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-260\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 255;\" id=\"mwCBs\"><span title=\"BIXI Montréal\" id=\"mwCB0\">BIXI.</a> First launched in 2009<sup about=\"#mwt1574\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-261\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-261\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-261\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 256;\" id=\"mwCB4\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwCB8\">[256]</span></a></sup> with Montreal-based PBSC Urban Solutions ICONIC bikes, the bicycle-sharing scheme has since grown its fleet to include 750 docking and charging stations across the different neighbourhoods with 9000 bikes available for users.<sup about=\"#mwt1578\" class=\"mw-ref reference\" id=\"cite_ref-262\" rel=\"dc:references\" typeof=\"mw:Extension/ref\" data-mw='{\"name\":\"ref\",\"attrs\":{},\"body\":{\"id\":\"mw-reference-text-cite_note-262\"}}'><a href=\"./Montreal#cite_note-262\" style=\"counter-reset: mw-Ref 257;\" id=\"mwCCA\"><span class=\"mw-reflink-text\" id=\"mwCCE\">[257]</span></a></sup> In what the <a rel=\"mw:WikiLink\" href=\"./Société_de_transport_de_Montréal\" title=\"Société de transport de Montréal\" id=\"mwCCI\">STM</a> states is a mission to combine different forms of mobility, transit card holders can now take advantage of their membership to also rent bicycles at select      = {{Official URL}}\n}}\n\n'''Montreal''' ({{small|[[Canadian English|CA]]:}} {{IPAc-en|audio=Montreal-English-pronunciation.oga|ˌ|m|ʌ|n|t|r|i|ˈ|ɔː|l}} {{respell|MUN|tree|AWL}}; {{Lang-fr|Montréal}} {{IPA-fr|mɔ̃ʁeal||Qc-Montréal.ogg}}) is the [[List of the largest municipalities in Canada by population|second most populous city]] in [[Canada]], the [[List of North American cities by population|tenth most populous city]] in [[North America]], and the [[List of towns in Quebec|most populous city]] in the [[Provinces and territories of Canada|province]] of [[Quebec]]. Founded in 1642 as ''[[Fort Ville-Marie|Ville-Marie]]'', or \"City of Mary\",<ref name=\"vieux.montreal.qc.ca\">{{cite web|url= https://www.vieux.montreal.qc.ca/histoire/eng/v_mara.htm|title= Old Montréal / Centuries of History|date= April 2000|access-date= March 26, 2009|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120630120639/http://www.vieux.montreal.qc.ca/histoire/eng/v_mara.htm|archive-date= June 30, 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> it is named after [[Mount Royal]],<ref name=\"montreal.about.com\">{{cite web |url= http://montreal.about.com/od/montrealparks/a/mount_royal_park_parc_du_mont_royal.htm |title= Mount Royal Park – Montreal's Mount Royal Park or Parc du Mont-Royal |publisher= montreal.about.com |access-date= November 16, 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110430052115/http://montreal.about.com/od/montrealparks/a/mount_royal_park_parc_du_mont_royal.htm |archive-date= April 30, 2011 |url-status=live }}</ref> the triple-peaked hill around which the early city of Ville-Marie was built.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Montreal |title=Montreal |encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica |edition=Online |access-date=April 19, 2022 |archive-date=March 28, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220328185743/https://www.britannica.com/place/Montreal |url-status=live }}</ref> The city is centred on the [[Island of Montreal]], which obtained its name from the same origin as the city,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://geonames.nrcan.gc.ca/education/montreal_e.php |title=Island of Montreal |access-date= February 7, 2008 |publisher=Natural Resources Canada |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531042123/http://geonames.nrcan.gc.ca/education/montreal_e.php |archive-date=May 31, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{citation\n | last = Poirier\n | first = Jean\n | year = 1979\n | title = Île de Montréal\n | volume = 5\n | issue = 1\n | pages = 6–8\n | place = Quebec\n | publisher = Canoma}}</ref> and a few much smaller peripheral islands, the largest of which is [[Île Bizard]]. The city is {{convert|196|km|abbr=on}} east of the national capital, [[Ottawa]], and {{convert|258|km|abbr=on}} southwest of the provincial capital, [[Quebec City]].\n\n{{As of|2021|post=,}} the city has a population of 1,762,949,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Government of Canada |first=Statistics Canada |date=February 9, 2022 |title=Profile table, Census Profile, 2021 Census of Population - Montréal, Ville (V) [Census subdivision], Quebec |url=https://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2021/dp-pd/prof/index.cfm?Lang=E |access-date=June 20, 2022 |website=www12.statcan.gc.ca |archive-date=February 9, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220209134619/https://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2021/dp-pd/prof/index.cfm?Lang=E |url-status=live }}</ref> and a [[Census Metropolitan Area#Census metropolitan areas|metropolitan]]  population of 4,291,732,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Government of Canada |first=Statistics Canada |date=November 15, 2017 |title=Illustrated Glossary - Census metropolitan area (CMA) and census agglomeration (CA) |url=https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/pub/92-195-x/2021001/geo/cma-rmr/cma-rmr-eng.htm |access-date=June 20, 2022 |website=www150.statcan.gc.ca |archive-date=June 20, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220620234156/https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/pub/92-195-x/2021001/geo/cma-rmr/cma-rmr-eng.htm |url-status=live }}</ref> making it the [[List of the largest municipalities in Canada by population|second-largest]] city, and [[List of census metropolitan areas and agglomerations in Canada|second-largest]] metropolitan area in Canada. [[French language|French]] is the city's official language.<ref>Chapter 1, article 1, {{cite web| year= 2008| title= Charte de la Ville de Montréal| url= live}}</ref><ref>Chapter 1, article 1, {{cite web| year= 2008| title= Charter of Ville de Montréal| url= https://www.canlii.org/en/qc/laws/stat/rsq-c-c-11.4/latest/rsq-c-c-11.4.html| access-date= name=\"cp2016-CD\"/>\n\nHistorically the commercial capital of Canada, Montreal was surpassed in population and economic strength by [[Toronto]] in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.toronto.ca/culture/history/history-shortversion.htm |title= City of Toronto, History Resources |publisher= City of Toronto |date= October 23, 2000 |access-date= April 13, 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110429115805/http://www.toronto.ca/culture/history/history-shortversion.htm |archive-date= April 29, 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Montreal remains an important centre of art, [[Culture of Montreal|culture]], literature, [[List of films shot in Montreal|film]] and television, music, commerce, aerospace, [[Transportation in Montreal|transport]], finance, pharmaceuticals, technology, design, [[Education in Montreal|education]], [[Tourism in Montreal|tourism]], food, fashion, video game development, and world affairs. Montreal is the location of the headquarters of the [[International Civil Aviation Organization]], and was named a [[UNESCO]] [[Design Cities (UNESCO)|City of Design]] in 2006.<ref name=\"UNESCO\">{{cite web|url= https://en.unesco.org/creative-cities/sites/creative-cities/files/RAPP_1215_MTL_Unesco_Design_en_siteunesco.pdf|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180201075806/https://en.unesco.org/creative-cities/sites/creative-cities/files/RAPP_1215_MTL_Unesco_Design_en_siteunesco.pdf |url-status=dead|archive-date= February 1, 2018|title= Montreal, Canada appointed a UNESCO City of Design |publisher= [[UNESCO]]|date= June 7, 2006 |access-date= September 16, 2009}}</ref><ref name=\"Monocle\">{{cite news|last=Wingrove|first=Josh|date=June 9, 2008|title=Vancouver and Montreal among 25 most livable cities|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|location=Canada|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/vancouver-and-montreal-among-25-most-livable-cities/article18451707/|access-date=November 16, 2020|archive-date=January 17, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210117194407/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/vancouver-and-montreal-among-25-most-livable-cities/article18451707/|url-status=live}}</ref> In 2017, Montreal was ranked the 12th-most liveable city in the world by the [[Economist Intelligence Unit]] in its annual [[Global Liveability Ranking]],<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.mtlblog.com/whats-happening/montreal-ranked-top-most-liveable-city-in-the-world|title= Montreal Ranked Top Most Livable City|website= Herald Sun|date= August 30, 2017|access-date= November 15, 2017|quote= The EIU's annual report, which ranks 140 major cities around the world based on their liveability, found Melbourne, Australia to be the most liveable city in the world. [...] Montreal doesn't make the list until number 12|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20171116080145/https://www.mtlblog.com/whats-happening/montreal-ranked-top-most-liveable-city-in-the-world|archive-date= November 16, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> although it slipped to rank 40 in the 2021 index, primarily due to stress on the healthcare system from the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref>{{cite web |date=June 8, 2021 |title=The Global Liveability Index 2021 - How the Covid-19 pandemic affected liveability worldwide |url=https://pages.eiu.com/rs/753-RIQ-438/images/global-liveability-index-2021-free-report.pdf |access-date=November 6, 2021 |website=[[Economist Intelligence Unit]] |archive-date=November 6, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211106090320/https://pages.eiu.com/rs/753-RIQ-438/images/global-liveability-index-2021-free-report.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref> It is regularly ranked as a top ten city in the world to be a university student in the [[QS World University Rankings]].<ref name=\"test\">{{cite web|url= https://www.topuniversities.com/city-rankings/2017|title= QS Best Student Cities 2017|work= Top Universities|access-date= February 22, 2017|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170218070525/https://www.topuniversities.com/city-rankings/2017|archive-date= February 18, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nMontreal has hosted multiple international conferences and events, including the [[Expo 67|1967 International and Universal Exposition]] and the [[1976 Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.olympic.org/montreal-1976-summer-Olympics|title= Montreal 1976|publisher= Olympic.org|access-date= January 2, 2016|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160104232458/http://www.olympic.org/montreal-1976-summer-olympics|archive-date= January 4, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ameriquefrancaise.org/en/article-605/Expo_67_in_Montreal,_a_Landmark_Event.html|title= Articles {{!}} Encyclopédie du patrimoine culturel de l'Amérique française – histoire, culture, religion, héritage|last= www.ixmedia.com|website= www.ameriquefrancaise.org|language= fr|access-date= April 9, 2016|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160331184328/http://www.ameriquefrancaise.org/en/article-605/Expo_67_in_Montreal,_a_Landmark_Event.html|archive-date= March 31, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> It is the only Canadian city to have held the Summer Olympics. [[Montreal Canadiens]] of the [[National Hockey League]], who have won the [[Stanley Cup]] more times than any other team.\n\n==Etymology and original names==\n{{See also|Name of Montreal}}\nIn the [[Ojibwe language]], the land is called {{lang|oj| Mooniyaang}}<ref>{{cite web|url= http://onishka.org/art-et-communaute/|title= Onishka – Art et Communaute|url-status=dead|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160220164827/http://onishka.org/art-et-communaute/|archive-date= February 20, 2016|df= mdy-all}}</ref> which was \"the first stopping place\" in the Ojibwe migration story as related in the [[seven fires prophecy]].\n\nIn the [[Mohawk language]], the land is called {{lang|moh|Tiohtià:ke}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://geonames.nrcan.gc.ca/education/montreal_e.php|title=Island of Montréal |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531042123/http://geonames.nrcan.gc.ca/education/montreal_e.php|website=Natural Resources Canada|archive-date=May 31, 2008|date=May 31, 2008|url-status= dead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.aptnnews.ca/national-news/montreal-turns-375-but-acknowledges-that-tiohtiake-is-much-older/ |title=Montreal turns 375 but acknowledges that Tiohtià:ke is
